title: China Moves to Increase Oversight of Tech Companies
text:
BEIJING—The eastern Chinese technology hub of Hangzhou will assign government representatives to work within 100 local companies including Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. , in a new indication of the Chinese government’s increasingly close monitoring of private companies.

Many of the officials will be assigned to companies operating in the technology and manufacturing sectors. For example, government representatives assigned to auto maker Zhejiang Geely Holding Group Co., which owns the Volvo brand, will help conduct government relations and information exchanges, according to a report published Friday on the official online news platform of Hangzhou’s home province of Zhejiang.

The vaguely worded statement didn’t elaborate, and Zhejiang officials didn’t respond to requests for comment. A spokesman for Geely confirmed the dispatching of a government official to the company, but declined to comment further. The action appears to affect only Chinese businesses; the statement named only three specific companies, all of which are based in Hangzhou: Alibaba, Geely and beverage giant Hangzhou Wahaha Group Co.

While it is unclear to what extent the government presence will affect daily operations at these companies, a commentary published Sunday in a Zhejiang state-run media outlet appeared aimed at calming fears that the government would intervene heavily in the companies’ operations.

The hand of local governments has in the past “stretched too far, managed too much and taken too much,” the commentary read, adding that the goal of the new measure was to fully respect the will of the companies. The government representatives will be stationed within the companies for one year as part of a pilot program, it said.

A spokeswoman for Hangzhou-based Alibaba said Monday that the online-retailing giant understood the government initiative as an attempt “to foster a better business environment.”

“The government representative will function as a bridge to the private sector, and will not interfere with the company’s operations,” she said.

Even so, the move to increase oversight of Chinese companies is likely to strengthen a view among some policy makers in the U.S. and the West that Chinese companies, whether state-owned or private, are effectively extensions of the Chinese government.

Under President Xi Jinping, China has been gradually giving more power to the state, increasingly steering investments toward state-owned enterprises rather than private businesses.

Last year, a state-controlled newspaper made public Alibaba founder Jack Ma ’s membership in the ruling Communist Party, which generated headlines both domestically and internationally because of Mr. Ma’s status as the country’s most prominent capitalist.

While the Communist Party has long established outposts within businesses, a view that Beijing is increasing its influence over private enterprise now underpins Washington’s campaign to persuade other countries to blacklist China’s Huawei Technologies Co., arguing that the Shenzhen-based telecommunications giant has no choice but to comply with any orders from Beijing to spy on its customers.

Huawei and fellow telecom-equipment maker ZTE Corp. , another object of American suspicion, have said they would deny any such requests. Beijing officials have said that Chinese companies must follow the law in countries where they operate.

Washington has recently broadened its cybersecurity warnings beyond Huawei and ZTE to include Alibaba, search-engine giant Baidu Inc. and Tencent Holdings Ltd. , which operates the WeChat instant-messaging and payments mobile app.

“Firms such as Huawei, Tencent, ZTE, Alibaba and Baidu have no meaningful ability to tell the Chinese Communist Party ‘no’ if officials decide to ask for their assistance,” Christopher Ford, U.S. assistant secretary of state for international security and nonproliferation, said in a speech this month. “Such aid may not necessarily occur routinely, but it certainly can occur—and presumably will—whenever the Party considers this useful and cares to demand it.”

Chinese companies are required to help the government hunt down criminal suspects and silence political dissent; Alibaba’s campus has a police outpost where employees report suspected crimes, and where police request data from Alibaba for their own investigations. Tech-company executives have said their technology helps make the country safer.

—Lekai Liu and Trefor Moss contributed to this article.
